Path: README.md
 1	# Getting Started with Create React App
 2	
 3	This project was bootstrapped with [Create React App](https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app).
 4	
 5	## Available Scripts
 6	
 7	In the project directory, you can run:
 8	
 9	### `npm start`
 10	
 11	Runs the app in the development mode.\
 12	Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) to view it in your browser.
 13	
 14	The page will reload when you make changes.\
 15	You may also see any lint errors in the console.
 16	
 17	### `npm test`
 18	
 19	Launches the test runner in the interactive watch mode.\
 20	See the section about [running tests](https://facebook.github.io/create-react-app/docs/running-tests) for more information.
 21	
 22	### `npm run build`
 23	
 24	Builds the app for production to the `build` folder.\
 25	It correctly bundles React in production mode and optimizes the build for the best performance.
 26	
 27	The build is minified and the filenames include the hashes.\
 28	Your app is ready to be deployed!
 29	
 30	See the section about [deployment](https://facebook.github.io/create-react-app/docs/deployment) for more information.
 31	
 32	### `npm run eject`
 33	
 34	**Note: this is a one-way operation. Once you `eject`, you can't go back!**
 35	
 36	If you aren't satisfied with the build tool and configuration choices, you can `eject` at any time. This command will remove the single build dependency from your project.
 37	
 38	Instead, it will copy all the configuration files and the transitive dependencies (webpack, Babel, ESLint, etc) right into your project so you have full control over them. All of the commands except `eject` will still work, but they will point to the copied scripts so you can tweak them. At this point you're on your own.
 39	
 40	You don't have to ever use `eject`. The curated feature set is suitable for small and middle deployments, and you shouldn't feel obligated to use this feature. However we understand that this tool wouldn't be useful if you couldn't customize it when you are ready for it.
 41	
 42	## Learn More
 43	
 44	You can learn more in the [Create React App documentation](https://facebook.github.io/create-react-app/docs/getting-started).

Path: RAILWAY_DEPLOYMENT.md
 1	# Railway Deployment Guide
 2	
 3	## Environment Variables Setup
 4	
 5	To properly deploy your Django application on Railway, you need to set the following environment variables in your Railway project dashboard:
 6	
 7	### Required Environment Variables
 8	
 9	1. **Database Configuration** (automatically provided by Railway PostgreSQL service):
 10	 - `DATABASE_URL` - Automatically set when you add PostgreSQL service
 11	
 12	2. **Django Configuration**:
 13	 - `SECRET_KEY` - Your Django secret key (generate a new one for production)
 14	 - `DEBUG` - Set to `False` for production
 15	 - `ALLOWED_HOSTS` - Your Railway domain (e.g., `your-app.railway.app`)
 16	 - `CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS` - Your Railway domain with protocol (e.g., `https://your-app.railway.app`)
 17	
 18	3. **Superuser Configuration** (recommended for production):
 19	 - `DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME` - Your admin username
 20	 - `DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL` - Your admin email
 21	 - `DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD` - Your admin password
 22	
 23	### Setting Environment Variables in Railway
 24	
 25	1. Go to your Railway project dashboard
 26	2. Click on your service
 27	3. Go to the "Variables" tab
 28	4. Add each environment variable with its value
 29	
 30	### Example Environment Variables
 31	
 32	```
 33	SECRET_KEY=your-super-secret-key-here
 34	DEBUG=False
 35	ALLOWED_HOSTS=your-app.railway.app
 36	CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS=https://your-app.railway.app
 37	DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME=youradmin
 38	DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL=admin@yourdomain.com
 39	DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD=your-secure-password
 40	```
 41	
 42	## Deployment Process
 43	
 44	1. **Connect Repository**: Connect your GitHub repository to Railway
 45	2. **Add PostgreSQL**: Add a PostgreSQL database service to your project
 46	3. **Set Environment Variables**: Configure all the variables listed above
 47	4. **Deploy**: Railway will automatically deploy using the Procfile
 48	
 49	## Troubleshooting
 50	
 51	### Superuser Creation Issues
 52	
 53	If you encounter superuser creation errors:
 54	
 55	1. **Check Environment Variables**: Ensure all superuser environment variables are set
 56	2. **Fallback Mode**: If environment variables are missing, the system will create a default admin user:
 57	 - Username: `admin`
 58	 - Email: `admin@example.com`
 59	 - Password: `admin123`
 60	 - **IMPORTANT**: Change these credentials immediately after first login!
 61	
 62	3. **Manual Creation**: You can also create a superuser manually using Railway's console:
 63	 ```bash
 64	 python manage.py createsuperuser
 65	 ```
 66	
 67	### Database Issues
 68	
 69	- Ensure PostgreSQL service is properly connected
 70	- Check that `DATABASE_URL` environment variable is set
 71	- Verify database migrations are running during deployment
 72	
 73	### Static Files Issues
 74	
 75	- Static files are collected automatically during deployment
 76	- Ensure `STATIC_ROOT` is properly configured in settings.py
 77	- WhiteNoise middleware is configured for serving static files
 78	
 79	## Security Notes
 80	
 81	1. **Never commit sensitive data** like secret keys or passwords to your repository
 82	2. **Use strong passwords** for your superuser account
 83	3. **Set DEBUG=False** in production
 84	4. **Configure proper ALLOWED_HOSTS** and CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS
 85	5. **Regularly update dependencies** for security patches
 86	
 87	## Post-Deployment Steps
...

Path: RAILWAY_DEPLOYMENT.md
 1	# Railway Deployment Guide
 2	
 3	## Environment Variables Setup
 4	
 5	To properly deploy your Django application on Railway, you need to set the following environment variables in your Railway project dashboard:
 6	
 7	### Required Environment Variables
 8	
 9	1. **Database Configuration** (automatically provided by Railway PostgreSQL service):
 10	 - `DATABASE_URL` - Automatically set when you add PostgreSQL service
 11	
 12	2. **Django Configuration**:
 13	 - `SECRET_KEY` - Your Django secret key (generate a new one for production)
 14	 - `DEBUG` - Set to `False` for production
 15	 - `ALLOWED_HOSTS` - Your Railway domain (e.g., `your-app.railway.app`)
 16	 - `CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS` - Your Railway domain with protocol (e.g., `https://your-app.railway.app`)
 17	
 18	3. **Superuser Configuration** (recommended for production):
 19	 - `DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME` - Your admin username
 20	 - `DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL` - Your admin email
 21	 - `DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD` - Your admin password
 22	
 23	### Setting Environment Variables in Railway
 24	
 25	1. Go to your Railway project dashboard
 26	2. Click on your service
 27	3. Go to the "Variables" tab
 28	4. Add each environment variable with its value
 29	
 30	### Example Environment Variables
 31	
 32	```
 33	SECRET_KEY=your-super-secret-key-here
 34	DEBUG=False
 35	ALLOWED_HOSTS=your-app.railway.app
 36	CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS=https://your-app.railway.app
 37	DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME=youradmin
 38	DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL=admin@yourdomain.com
 39	DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD=your-secure-password
 40	```
 41	
 42	## Deployment Process
 43	
 44	1. **Connect Repository**: Connect your GitHub repository to Railway
 45	2. **Add PostgreSQL**: Add a PostgreSQL database service to your project
 46	3. **Set Environment Variables**: Configure all the variables listed above
 47	4. **Deploy**: Railway will automatically deploy using the Procfile and deploy.sh script
 48	
 49	### Deployment Architecture
 50	
 51	- **Build Phase**: Static files are collected using nixpacks.toml
 52	- **Release Phase**: Database migrations and superuser creation via deploy.sh
 53	- **Runtime Phase**: Gunicorn serves the Django application
 54	
 55	## Troubleshooting
 56	
 57	### Superuser Creation Issues
 58	
 59	If you encounter superuser creation errors:
 60	
 61	1. **Check Environment Variables**: Ensure all superuser environment variables are set
 62	2. **Fallback Mode**: If environment variables are missing, the system will create a default admin user:
 63	 - Username: `admin`
 64	 - Email: `admin@example.com`
 65	 - Password: `admin123`
 66	 - **IMPORTANT**: Change these credentials immediately after first login!
 67	
 68	3. **Manual Creation**: You can also create a superuser manually using Railway's console:
 69	 ```bash
 70	 python manage.py createsuperuser
 71	 ```
 72	
 73	### Database Issues
 74	
 75	- Ensure PostgreSQL service is properly connected
 76	- Check that `DATABASE_URL` environment variable is set
 77	- Verify database migrations are running during deployment
 78	
 79	### Static Files Issues
 80	
 81	- Static files are collected automatically during deployment
 82	- Ensure `STATIC_ROOT` is properly configured in settings.py
 83	- WhiteNoise middleware is configured for serving static files
 84	
 85	## Security Notes
 86	
 87	1. **Never commit sensitive data** like secret keys or passwords to your repository
 88	2. **Use strong passwords** for your superuser account
 89	3. **Set DEBUG=False** in production
 90	4. **Configure proper ALLOWED_HOSTS** and CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS
 91	5. **Regularly update dependencies** for security patches
 92	
 93	## Post-Deployment Steps
 94	
 95	1. **Test the application**: Visit your Railway URL to ensure it's working
 96	2. **Access admin panel**: Go to `/admin/` and login with your superuser credentials
 97	3. **Change default credentials**: If using fallback credentials, change them immediately
 98	4. **Monitor logs**: Check Railway logs for any errors or issues
...

 4	# This script runs database operations that require a live database connection

 7	
 8	echo "Starting Railway deployment script..."
 9	
 10	# Check environment variables
 11	echo "Checking environment variables..."
 12	echo "DATABASE_URL is set: $([ -n "$DATABASE_URL" ] && echo "YES" || echo "NO")"
 13	if [ -n "$DATABASE_URL" ]; then
 14	 echo "DATABASE_URL starts with: $(echo $DATABASE_URL | cut -c1-20)..."
 15	fi

 98	echo "Collecting static files..."
 99	python manage.py collectstatic --noinput --clear || echo "Static files collection failed, continuing..."
 100	
 101	# Create superuser if needed
 102	echo "Creating superuser..."
 103	if python manage.py create_superuser_from_env --skip-if-exists; then
 104	 echo "Superuser creation completed"
 105	else
 106	 echo "WARNING: Superuser creation failed, but continuing..."
 107	fi

Path: test_superuser_creation.py
 1	#!/usr/bin/env python
 2	"""
 3	Test script to verify superuser creation works locally before deployment
 4	"""
 5	import os
 6	import sys
 7	import django
 8	from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line
 9	
 10	# Add the project directory to Python path
 11	sys.path.insert(0, os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)))
 12	
 13	# Set Django settings module
 14	os.environ.setdefault('DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE', 'amazon.settings')
 15	
 16	# Setup Django
 17	django.setup()
 18	
 19	from django.contrib.auth import get_user_model
 20	
 21	def test_superuser_creation():
 22	 """Test the superuser creation command"""
 23	 User = get_user_model()
 24	 
 25	 print("Testing superuser creation...")
 26	 
 27	 # Clear any existing superusers for testing
 28	 User.objects.filter(is_superuser=True).delete()
 29	 print("Cleared existing superusers")
 30	 
 31	 # Test 1: With environment variables
 32	 print("\n--- Test 1: With environment variables ---")
 33	 os.environ['DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME'] = 'testadmin'
 34	 os.environ['DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL'] = 'test@example.com'
 35	 os.environ['DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD'] = 'testpass123'
 36	 
 37	 execute_from_command_line(['manage.py', 'create_superuser_from_env'])
 38	 
 39	 # Verify creation
 40	 if User.objects.filter(username='testadmin', is_superuser=True).exists():
 41	 print(" Test 1 PASSED: Superuser created with environment variables")
 42	 else:
 43	 print(" Test 1 FAILED: Superuser not created")
 44	 
 45	 # Test 2: Without environment variables (fallback)
 46	 print("\n--- Test 2: Without environment variables (fallback) ---")
 47	 # Clear environment variables
 48	 for key in ['DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME', 'DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL', 'DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD']:
 49	 if key in os.environ:
 50	 del os.environ[key]
 51	 
 52	 # Clear existing users
 53	 User.objects.filter(is_superuser=True).delete()
 54	 
 55	 execute_from_command_line(['manage.py', 'create_superuser_from_env'])
 56	 
 57	 # Verify fallback creation
 58	 if User.objects.filter(username='admin', is_superuser=True).exists():
 59	 print(" Test 2 PASSED: Superuser created with fallback credentials")
 60	 else:
 61	 print(" Test 2 FAILED: Superuser not created with fallback")
 62	 
 63	 # Test 3: Skip if exists
 64	 print("\n--- Test 3: Skip if superuser exists ---")
 65	 execute_from_command_line(['manage.py', 'create_superuser_from_env', '--skip-if-exists'])
 66	 
 67	 # Should not create another user
 68	 superuser_count = User.objects.filter(is_superuser=True).count()
 69	 if superuser_count == 1:
 70	 print(" Test 3 PASSED: Skipped creation when superuser exists")
 71	 else:
 72	 print(f" Test 3 FAILED: Expected 1 superuser, found {superuser_count}")
 73	 
 74	 print("\n--- Test Summary ---")
 75	 print("All tests completed. Check the output above for results.")
 76	 
 77	 # Clean up
 78	 User.objects.filter(is_superuser=True).delete()
 79	 print("Cleaned up test superusers")
 80	
 81	if __name__ == '__main__':
 82	 test_superuser_creation()

Path: RAILWAY_SETUP_GUIDE.md
 1	# Railway PostgreSQL Setup Guide
 2	
 3	## The Problem
 4	You're seeing this error: `could not translate host name "postgres.railway.internal" to address: Name or service not known`
 5	
 6	This means your Django service can't connect to the PostgreSQL database because:
 7	1. PostgreSQL service is not added to your Railway project, OR
 8	2. PostgreSQL service is not properly connected to your Django service
 9	
 10	## Step-by-Step Fix
 11	
 12	### 1. Add PostgreSQL Service to Railway
 13	
 14	1. Go to your Railway project dashboard
 15	2. Click the **"+ New"** button
 16	3. Select **"Database"** **"Add PostgreSQL"**
 17	4. Railway will create a new PostgreSQL service
 18	
 19	### 2. Connect Services (CRITICAL STEP)
 20	
 21	This is the most important step that's often missed:
 22	
 23	1. In your Railway project dashboard, you should now see TWO services:
 24	 - Your Django app service (from GitHub)
 25	 - PostgreSQL database service
 26	
 27	2. **Connect the services**:
 28	 - Click on your **Django service** (not the database)
 29	 - Go to the **"Variables"** tab
 30	 - You should see `DATABASE_URL` automatically appear
 31	 - If you don't see it, the services aren't connected properly
 32	
 33	3. **If DATABASE_URL is missing**:
 34	 - Go to your Django service settings
 35	 - Look for "Service Connections" or "Connected Services"
 36	 - Make sure PostgreSQL is connected
 37	 - Railway should automatically inject the `DATABASE_URL` variable
 38	
 39	### 3. Verify Environment Variables
 40	
 41	In your Django service's Variables tab, you should see:
 42	- `DATABASE_URL` (automatically set by Railway when PostgreSQL is connected)
 43	- Any custom variables you set (SECRET_KEY, DEBUG, etc.)
 44	
 45	### 4. Redeploy
 46	
 47	After connecting the services:
 48	1. Go to your Django service
 49	2. Click **"Deploy"** or trigger a new deployment
 50	3. Watch the logs - you should see successful database connection
 51	
 52	## Alternative: Manual DATABASE_URL Setup
 53	
 54	If automatic connection doesn't work:
 55	
 56	1. Go to your **PostgreSQL service**
 57	2. Go to **"Connect"** tab
 58	3. Copy the **"Postgres Connection URL"**
 59	4. Go to your **Django service** **"Variables"** tab
 60	5. Add a new variable:
 61	 - Name: `DATABASE_URL`
 62	 - Value: (paste the connection URL)
 63	
 64	## Troubleshooting
 65	
 66	### Check if PostgreSQL is Running
 67	1. Go to PostgreSQL service in Railway
 68	2. Check the "Deployments" tab
 69	3. Make sure it shows "Active" status
 70	
 71	### Check Service Connection
 72	1. In your Django service, go to Variables tab
 73	2. Look for `DATABASE_URL` - it should start with `postgresql://`
 74	3. If missing, the services aren't connected
 75	
 76	### Check Logs
 77	1. Go to Django service "Deployments" tab
 78	2. Click on latest deployment
 79	3. Check logs for database connection messages
 80	
 81	## Expected Success Messages
 82	
 83	After fixing, you should see in your deployment logs:
 84	```
 85	Database configuration:
 86	 Engine: django.db.backends.postgresql
 87	 Host: postgres.railway.internal
 88	 Port: 5432
 89	Database connection successful
 90	Migrations completed successfully
 91	Superuser creation completed
 92	```
 93	
 94	## Still Having Issues?
 95	
 96	If you're still seeing connection errors:
 97	
 98	1. **Delete and recreate** the PostgreSQL service
 99	2. **Ensure both services are in the same Railway project**
 100	3. **Check Railway's status page** for any service outages
 101	4. **Contact Railway support** if the issue persists
 102	
 103	The key is making sure Railway automatically injects the `DATABASE_URL` environment variable when you connect the PostgreSQL service to your Django service.
...

 2	"""Django's command-line utility for administrative tasks."""
 3	import os
 4	import sys
 5	
 6	
 7	def main():
 8	 """Run administrative tasks."""
 9	 os.environ.setdefault('DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE', 'amazon.settings')
 10	 try:
 11	 from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line
 12	 except ImportError as exc:
 13	 raise ImportError(
 14	 "Couldn't import Django. Are you sure it's installed and "
 15	 "available on your PYTHONPATH environment variable? Did you "
 16	 "forget to activate a virtual environment?"
 17	 ) from exc
 18	 execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
 19	
 20	
 21	if __name__ == '__main__':
 22	 main()

 5	## Available Scripts
 6

 8	
 9	### `npm start`

 12	Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) to view it in your browser.
 13	
 14	The page will reload when you make changes.\

 2	import os
 3	from django.core.management.base import BaseCommand
 4	from django.contrib.auth import get_user_model
 5	
 6	class Command(BaseCommand):
 7	 help = "Creates a superuser from environment variables with fallback options"
 8	
 9	 def add_arguments(self, parser):
 10	 parser.add_argument(
 11	 '--skip-if-exists',
 12	 action='store_true',
 13	 help='Skip creation if any superuser already exists',
 14	 )
 15	
 16	 def handle(self, *args, **options):
 17	 User = get_user_model()
 18	
 19	 # Check if we should skip if any superuser exists
 20	 if options['skip_if_exists'] and User.objects.filter(is_superuser=True).exists():
 21	 self.stdout.write(self.style.WARNING("Superuser already exists. Skipping creation."))
 22	 return
 23	
 24	 # Try to get credentials from environment variables
 25	 username = os.environ.get("DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME")
 26	 email = os.environ.get("DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL")
 27	 password = os.environ.get("DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD")
 28	
 29	 # Fallback credentials if environment variables are not set
 30	 if not all([username, email, password]):
